titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Northern Virginia Oral History Project
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections and Archives NVOHP001

defitem.label: Funding:
defitem.item: Web version of the finding aid funded in part by a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

archdesc.runner: Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University Libraries

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University
did.unittitle: Northern Virginia Oral History Project

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Northern Virginia Oral History Project, Special Collections & Archives, George Mason University Libraries

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Northern Virginia Oral History Project Collection is comprised of two series. The eighty interviews in Series 1, taped between 1962 and 1983, document community and family life, careers, etc. in the Northern Virginia Area. The sixteen interviews in Series 2, conducted in 1982-1983, deal primarily with changes in Northern Virginia since World War II.
The collection was previously housed in the Fairfax County Library from 1962-1983. It was transferred to George Mason University Libraries in 1984.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The Northern Virginia Oral History Collection contains 96 taped interviews of Northern Virginia residents. Transcripts or abstracts accompany most of the recordings. Topics such as agriculture, development, education, health, politics, transportation, and religion, with respect to Northern Virginia in the 19th and 20th centuries, are discussed. Total volume of the collection is 1 cubic foot or 1.5 linear feet.
